segments.text: OK ... well , then how much is one jin ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Ginseng comes in 6 different grades . It runs from 5,000 to 30,000 NT a jin .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: 30,000 NT for ginseng ? ! Do I have to buy a whole jin ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: You can get a liang if you want . A liang is one-sixteenth of a jin . That would be 330NT .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: Whew ! That sounds more like my price range . I'll take two liangs .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: I'll have my brother cut some for you .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: This little red fruit looks good . What's it good for ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: That's a lucky fruit called hong zat ! People say that if you eat them , you will have your first son very soon !
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: Uh ... , I'm not even married yet . How about this brown dried fruit ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Gui yuan are lucky , too ! If you eat them , you'll have a very sweet life !
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: And how about these little brown chips ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: Oh , that's deer horn . That helps you ... umm , how should I put it ?
segments.speaker: S2
